docs.lead_paragraph: The denial of economic reality that permeated Wall Street a few years ago has now migrated to Washington. On Wall Street, when companies did not generate the promised profits to justify the bubble in stock prices, many analysts told investors that profits did not matter. A new economy would be gauged by other measures, they insisted. Today, in similar fashion, as the federal budget has plunged into the red over the past two years, President Bush's economic team is telling the nation that deficits no longer matter. At first, perhaps, the claim seemed plausible. Damage to the economy was not yet evident. And I, for one, am not a deficit hawk. At times, deficits are necessary to stimulate economic growth, and their dampening impact on private investment is occasionally exaggerated. But because of the Bush administration's policies and a weak economy, deficits are now approaching unmanageable levels, as they did in the 1980's. In fact, the federal government's fiscal health has deteriorated at a pace so stunning that few have yet caught up with the facts.

docs.lead_paragraph: CORPORATE America has plenty of reasons to trim the lavish perks it ritually bestows on its top executives. Amid accounting and fraud scandals, the depressed stock market and a backlash against corporate excess, no executive wants to be caught with the fresh flowers, New York Knicks tickets, laundry service and other privileges once enjoyed by John F. Welch Jr., the retired chairman and chief executive of General Electric. Mr. Welch's big perk package came to light last September, prompting outcries by investors and corporate-governance experts and an investigation by securities industry regulators. The company later revoked some of Mr. Welch's privileges, and he said he would pay for the rest -- around $2.5 million a year.

docs.lead_paragraph: In its first major step to remedy an £800 million ($1.25 billion) capital shortfall, the insurer Royal and Sun Alliance will sell its Healthcare and Assistance business for £147 million ($230 million). The unit is being bought by a newly formed group of its managers and former managers, backed by Barclays Private Equity and by the Bank of Scotland. The insurer will also release £100 million ($156 million) in capital from the unit. Analysts' reaction to the news was mixed. While some felt the unit had fetched a decent price, others expressed concern that Royal and Sun Alliance is disposing of some of its most attractive assets, ultimately limiting its growth prospects. Under pressure to quickly turn a deficit into a surplus, the insurer also intends to issue shares in Promina, its Australian and New Zealand unit, sell some assets in the United States and reduce staff. Christine Whitehouse (NYT)

docs.lead_paragraph: As the National Guard and reserves mobilized, North Dakota State University had 95 students called to duty. The Sherwin Williams paint store in Bismarck had four out of its five employees deployed. The Bobcat factory in Gwinner, population 700, lost 14 employees. Hillsboro lost half its police force. Of course, the town only had two officers to begin with. ''One minute you have a full-time guy, the next minute you are working all by yourself again,'' said Ray Weber, the police chief for the town of 1,500.

McGreevey's proposed budget, everyone wailing about the forecasts presented could be assured that there is indeed something worse than the dismal year they are facing. That would be the year after. For that matter, the economists and state officials who testified Tuesday and today made it clear that any visions of recovery were rapidly receding and with them the hope of repairing state government without fundamental, longstanding changes in taxing and spending habits.

docs.lead_paragraph: States can require managed health care plans to accept any qualified doctor who wants to be a participating provider, the Supreme Court ruled today in a unanimous decision that resolved a significant legal dispute about state health care regulation. At the urging of doctors and patients, many states have enacted what are generally known as ''any willing provider'' laws, to prevent H.M.O.'s from limiting the pool of doctors or from retaliating against doctors who recommend too many treatments or complain about working conditions.
